PT1M36S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Privately owned companies with revenues above $100 million should not have to publicly disclose how much tax they pay because the public does not understand taxation, a Senate committee says.
The government-dominated Senate committee recommended that a bill to shield wealthy business owners from having to reveal their company's tax contribution should proceed to prevent the information from potentially being "misused and misinterpreted".
The Economics Legislation Committee cited a "poor understanding" of the difference between turnover and taxable income as one of the "strong reasons" to wind back tax transparency measures introduced by Labor in 2013.
Gina Rinehart at the maiden speech of Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce in 2013. Photo: Andrew Meares
The committee found the transparency law had the potential to "result in the publication of taxation information of privately owned companies that could be misused, misinterpreted or mislead due to poor understanding of the relationship between gross accounting turnover and net taxable income".
Advertisement It also cited the "long-standing tenet of Australia's tax laws" that taxpayers' affairs remain private between the taxpayer and the Australian Tax Office and that disclosure could "place a company at a competitive disadvantage".
In a fiery dissenting report, ALP and Greens senators on the committee said the arguments used to justify shielding businesses are "absurd, illogical, and often lacking any evidence".
James Packer, pictured with former Liberal leader Tony Abbott in 2012. Photo: Jesse MArlow
"This bill has few supporters, and the government is evidently doing the bidding of a tiny number of very wealthy individuals. There were just a handful of submissions to this inquiry, and other than tax consultants and tax lawyers servicing large private companies, the only corporation to make a contribution was Teys Australia, a privately owned meat processing joint venture with the American company Cargill, based in Brisbane," the dissenting senators said.
When the bill was first announced, the reason cited was that wealthy owners could be targeted for kidnappings and extortion attempts if their tax affairs were made public.
Fairfax Media revealed in June that the Abbott government had not requested or received any advice from security agencies, including the Australian Federal Police, to verify any threat before agreeing to repeal disclosure laws that were due to begin this year.
Lindsay Fox. Photo: Arsineh Houspian
Earlier this month, entrepreneur Dick Smith said Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull would be "ratting on typical Australians who pay their tax" if the Coalition winds back transparency. He said he did not believe there was any greater threat to individuals because most are already on the BRW Rich List and flaunt their wealth with "waterfront properties, big boats, and big planes".
The committee only made one reference to any security threat in its findings: "These companies are typically owned by families and, without the proposed exemption, the privacy of these families and in some cases their personal security may be jeopardised," it said.
The Australian Tax Office will begin publishing the tax paid by large private companies from mid-December unless the Coalition can convince the crossbench to support its 'Better Targeting the Income Tax Transparency Laws' amendment.
Dick Smith: Laws would be "ratting on typical Australians who pay their tax". Photo: James Brickwood
Fairfax Media understands the government still needs the support of senators Ricky Muir, Glen Lazarus and Zhenya "Dio" Wang if it is to succeed on passing the bill.
An estimated 700-1000 companies with turnover in excess of $100 million are due to disclose their tax affairs this year. They include James Packer's Consolidated Press Holdings, Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting, Lindsay Fox's Linfox and the scandal-plagued 7-Eleven convenience store empire of Russ Withers.
The committee report cited the bill's explanatory memorandum which says it will "promote human rights through the prohibition on interference with privacy contained in Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights".
Drafted in 1966, the covenant was drafted to prevent governments arbitrarily or unlawfully invading the privacy of people's homes and bedrooms.
Article 17 was used in 1994 by Nicholas Toonen to challenge the Tasmanian government's laws that made it illegal for consenting same-sex couples to have sex in private. The case led to the repeal of the last sodomy law in Australia.
In the dissenting report, Labor said: "Invoking this instrument is an obnoxious attempt to misguide the public, press, and the Parliament. It has no connection to tax privacy, and the claim deserves both derision and ridicule."
